title: refactor: use built-in option to strip compiled WASM
body: docs: https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/reference/profiles.html#strip

title: store: remove ‘pub’ from StoreConfig constants
body: The ‘pub’ is not necessary any longer.

title: store: move StoreConfig to separate file
body:
With that make a few minor changes to the code.

Firstly, change type of col_state_cache_size and block_size fields to
bytesize::ByteSize so that they are strongly typed.  With that change,
introduce col_cache_size which returns cache size for given column.

Secondly, change how default_* functinos used by serde deserialisation
are defined.  Rather than them returning constans they construct
a default StoreConfig object and return value of corresponding field.
This also allows the DEFAULT_* fields in the structure to no longr be
public.

And lastly, make all functions const because why not?

title: test: add imports to runtime fuzzing setup
body:
Imports are specified by implementing [`available_imports`](https://docs.rs/wasm-smith/0.10.0/wasm_smith/trait.Config.html#method.available_imports) for `ModuleConfig`,
which is then used in [`wasm_smith::ConfiguredModule<ModuleConfig>`](https://docs.rs/wasm-smith/0.10.0/wasm_smith/struct.ConfiguredModule.html).
Previously, `wasm_smith::Module` and its default configuration were used.

To get the imports of near host functions, test contract [`test-contract-rs`](https://github.com/near/nearcore/tree/master/runtime/near-test-contracts/test-contract-rs) is
used. This contract provides the method [`sanity_check`](https://github.com/near/nearcore/blob/e577a2c13d22720a27308afafd24e3e2d3c4523f/runtime/near-test-contracts/test-contract-rs/src/lib.rs#L877-L1227) which calls every host
function, hence ensuring they are all imported.

Issue #6539 

To run fuzzing:
https://github.com/near/nearcore/blob/e577a2c13d22720a27308afafd24e3e2d3c4523f/runtime/near-vm-runner/README.md?plain=1#L45

title: fix: don't show 0 -> 0 changes in continuous estimation
body:
Simple division seems to do the trick:

* if both numerator and denominator are zero, we get a NaN, which isn't
  larger then threshold.
* if only deom is zero, we get +inf

title: chain: normalise number formatting in status line
body:
Use the same code for formatting numbers in human-readable format.
The algorithm will show three significant digits of the number and
use appropriate k, M, G etc. prefixes.

Use SI prefixes for all the numbers.  It makes no sense to use binary
prefixes for bandwidth.  An argument could be made that binary prefixes
work better with memory (since RAM sticks have sizes which are powers
of two) but using decimal prefixes everywhere simplifies the code.

Issue: https://github.com/near/nearcore/issues/2454

title: chain: refactor AdversarialControls to reduce conditional compilation
body:
Provide an ‘empty’ definition of AdversarialControls which is used
when test_features compilation feature is not enabled.  This empty
definition provides accessors to all adversarial controls always
returning non-adversarial values.

Based on the test_features flag either the empty definition (if it’s
missing) or definitinons where adversarial behaviour can be enabled
(if it’s present) is used.

With this refactoring most `#[cfg(feature = "test_features")]` guards
can be removed.  This simplifies the code by removing some of the
syntax noise.

While at it, also change the controls such that rather than using
RwLock all the options are stored in atomic values.  This further
simplifies the code slightly.

title: refactor: don't type-erase IO errors
body:
This changes from `IOErr(String)` to `IOErr(io::Error)`, so we don't
lose specific error. The consequence here is that Error is no longer Eq,
so the tests are adjusted accordingly.

In general, errors should be neither Eq nor Clone, they are not values.

Often times, when an error feels like a value, it means that the error
type wants to be split in two, from `Result<T, Error>` into
`Result<Result<T, InvalidTx>, io::Error>` where the outer Error captures
real errors/exceptions (such as the database having a bad day), and
internal error is just a normal outcome of a request processing.

title: refactor: simplify chain::Error
body: closes #6797

title: fix: make sure that `cargo test` can be killed with ctrl+c
body:
I am not sure why we were catching ctrl+c in the first place. This was
introduced in #4229 I think. But messing up with signal handlers in
tests doesn't feel right and, indeed, prevents tests from being killed.

Test Plan
---------

Manual testing: running `cargo t -p integration-tests` and then killing
it in the middle with ctrl+c leaves the test running in the background
before this PR, and properly kills the process after.

title: Observability: Instrument syncing
body: Issue #6788

title: Update strum dependency to 0.24
Send batches of spans asynchronously for better performance when opentelemetry feature is enabled.
fix(network): PeerStore's cache gets out of sync
body:
`PeerStore` maintains its internal cache in two maps:
https://github.com/near/nearcore/blob/dddbb6a9691d0be59bef59cf50bbf096e1b617c8/chain/network/src/peer_manager/peer_store.rs#L47-L51

In [`remove_expired`](https://github.com/near/nearcore/blob/dddbb6a9691d0be59bef59cf50bbf096e1b617c8/chain/network/src/peer_manager/peer_store.rs#L282-L299) peers are deleted (via `delete_peers`) *only* from `peer_states`
but not from `addr_peers`.

Assume a peer with address `x` was deleted via `remove_expired`. When learning
about a new indirect peer which has the same address `x`, that information is
not stored due to `x` still being in `addr_peers`:
https://github.com/near/nearcore/blob/dddbb6a9691d0be59bef59cf50bbf096e1b617c8/chain/network/src/peer_manager/peer_store.rs#L381-L389

This PR updates `delete_peers` to remove addresses from `addr_peers` and
adds `test_delete_peers`.

There's only one other call site of `delete_peers`: `PeerStore::new`. Its
behavior is not changed by this PR. The peers it deletes aren't added to the
internal cache.

title: feat: Improve add fn key estimation
body:
Test short and long method names in the gas cost estimation for adding a
function call access. Also subtract the receipt creation cost.

title: feat: Adjust AltBn128 gas costs
body:
Per element costs have still been on the per-byte values. To compensate,
multiply by factor equal to the size of the corresponding element.

- g1_multiexp: 96
- g1_sum: 65
- pairing_check: 192

Additionally, all AltBn128 parameters are now rounded to whole Ggas.

title: chore: Delete obsolete estimator scripts
body:
`ci.sh`: No longer used because the buildkite pipeline has ben archived.
The same task, among others, is performed by continuous estimation.

`compare_costs.py` and `safety_multiplier.py`: Both operate on the
replaced JSON runtime config format. We have not used these scripts in
a long time, since estimations did not produce complete JSONs anyway.
But there always was the chance that we might go that way again.
Now, however,  that #6693 replaced the JSON format, these scripts are
truly obsolete and better of deleted.

title: chore: Remove estimator from release build
body:
The parameter estimator is not part of released binaries and only
slows down `make release` unnecessarily.

Users of the estimator are adivised to to build manually.
Or, when running a full estimation and collecting the data in the
warehouse using `cargo run -p estimator-warehouse -- estimate`,
then compilation is automatic.

title: test: Remove old runtime config tests
body:
Now that the new runtime config format has been merged, we can get rid
of the old JSON files that were kept to ensure the new format remains
compatible.

Use insta snapshot testing to verifythat the JSON representation is not
changed unexpectedly. This also replaces the hash comparison that needed
to be updated manually after every change.

title: chain: update build_chain test to use insta
body:
With insta it’s much simpler to update the hashes when they change.

Furthermore, observe that empty_chain test doesn’t actually test
anything that build_chain doesn’t test already so remove it.

title: Replace ‘nightly_protocol_features’ with ‘nightly’ feature
body:
The ‘nightly_protocol’ and ‘nightly_protocol_features’ Cargo features
are a bit confusing to new and old developers alike.  They two are
almost always paired together which raises the question why they are
separate features.

What’s worse, in test we often test for the ‘nightly_protocol’ feature
with the assumption that ‘nightly_protocol_features’ is enabled as
well.  This may result in people trying to run tests with only the
former feature and getting bogus test failures.

But that’s not all.  What makes situation even more confusing is that
‘nightly_protocol_features’ enables ‘nightly_protocol’ in most of the
Cargo configuration.

To simplify the most common case where both features are enabled,
rename ‘nightly_protocol_features’ to ‘nightly’ and change it so that
it always forces ‘nightly_protocol’ feature on.

The less common case where a single protocol feature is tested
(i.e. ’--features nightly_protocol,some_nightly_feature’) isn’t
affected at all.

title: network: Remove blacklisted peers from `PeerStore` (and `Store`)
body:
Previously, blacklisted peers were banned with ReasonForBan::Blacklisted
but not removed. Indepentent of a ban, new connections from blacklisted
peers are rejected[1].

[1] https://github.com/near/nearcore/blob/55d0e03b52d1eece08ce4ba91cc726c9134087e9/chain/network/src/peer_manager/peer_manager_actor.rs#L2081-L2085

`ReasonForBan::Blacklisted` isn't used anymore. It's not removed,
though, assuming that there might be db instances which still contain
peers banned with `ReasonForBan::Blacklisted`.

Fixes: #6521

title: test: Snapshot tests for estimator warehouse
body:
Restyling tests for commands to be more e2e and more data-driven.
The insta crate is used, since it makes life easier and it is already
used in other parts of the code base.

Previous tests were trying to cover all pub(crate) methods, which is not
the best style for us. Instead, use input and output strings that are
independent of the implementation.

title: Option to disable colored log output.
body:
Tested by running a betanet node for 5 minutes. Both runs generated ~3.6M log lines, but file sizes differ 1.5x.
--color=always - 1.5GB
--color=never - 1.0GB

Fix #6548

title: use the mock_node framework in a benchmark
body:
This sets up sync performance benchmarks using the existing mock_node tool. The basic setup right now is that we check in tarballs containing sample home dirs in the mock_node/benches directory, and then start a node that will sync from a mock network feeding blocks from that home directory, measuring the time it takes for `view_client.send(GetBlock::latest())` to pass a certain height.

Checking in tarballs like this will only be practical for small sample directories, but it should be possible to use the code here to run benchmarks on larger sample directories not checked in to git, possibly with the help of some other tool.

run with `cargo bench -p mock_node -- mock_node_sync_empty` to run the quicker benchmark, or omit the testname to run all.

title: Consistently use spans to instrument important node functions
body:
Make logging more useful for viewing tracing in a distributed tracing system, such as Jaeger.

The goal is to group spans together if they are triggered by a single event. For example, calling `check_triggers()` and processing accepted blocks is triggered by a single network message. Another example is parallel processing of chunks, it's much better to track them as children of a parent span.

These changes make logging more verbose by 20% in terms of the number of lines. Measured by running a betanet node for 5 minutes.

title: create Chain::preprocess_block
body: This PR creates a Chain::preprocess_block which just calls ChainUpdate::preprocess_block. The eventual plan is to move everything in ChainUpdate::preprocess_block to the new function, but that requires a lot of code refactoring, so we are doing this as a first step.

title: move mark_block_as_challenged outside of preprocess_block
refactor: vendor pwasm_utils
body:
See https://github.com/near/nearcore/issues/6659.

I did more-or-less direct copy-paste, with slight adjustments of various
paths and re-railing the testing infra from wabt to wasm-tools. I think
it would be great to refactor the code further to make it mesh better
with nearcore style, but I don't think this is strictly required.

title: chain-primitives: use StorageError kind and avoid string allocation
body:
Firstly, in runtime use StorageError kind for converting StorageError
errors to Error rather than formatting them to string and treating
them as Other.

Secondly, self.get_epoch_and_valset in tests already returns an Error
so there’s no need to map it to anything.

Lastly, get rid of `From<String>` implementation and in the one place
it was needed (`gc_col_block_per_height`) use a closure with explicit
ErrorKind::Other construction.  This gets rid of a string allocation
which used to always happen; now it only happens when error is
returned.

reimplemented handshake test in rust

title: fixing a typo in debug HTML
Reduce verbosity of transaction receiving/forwarding.
body: Spams betanet logs.

title: pytest: allow bumping protocol version one more than rc in testnet
body:
The `test_protocol_versions` test in `upgradable.py` ensures that we
never increase protocol version by more than one between releases.  It
looks at executable currently running on mainnet and compares it with
code on master branch.  The problem arises when there’s have an rc
running in testnet with increased version.

Consider the following:
- 1.25.0 with protocol version 52 is deployed in mainnet,
- 1.26.0-rc.1 with protocol version 53 is deployed in testnet and
- we want to change protocol version on master to 54.

This should be allowed but the test will fail.

Change the test such that it fetches latest deployed executable on
testnet and takes it into consideration when making the protocol
version comparison.

The rules are that protocol version on master can be at most one more
than what’s on testnet; and protocol version on testnet can be at most
one more than what’s running on mainnet.

Issue: https://github.com/near/nearcore/issues/4956
Fixes: https://github.com/near/nearcore/issues/6764

title: client: don’t update validators produced counters when syncing

labels.name: T-node
labels.description: Team: issues relevant to the node experience team

body:
EpochManager::get_validator_info call querying information by block
hash turns out to be quite expensive while node is synchronising.

Normally, EpochManager maintains validator information up to the
latest final block.  With that, calling get_validator_info with
a block hash usually needs to iterate over only a handful of blocks
until it hits the latest final block and then can read the already
aggregated data.

However, while node is syncing, the aggregated data is not maintained.
This means that getting validator info for a given block requires
iteration over all blocks until start of the epoch.  This is an
expensive operation.

EpochManager::get_validator_info is called each time stats line is
generated.  When synchronising this ends up taking a up all of the
processing time to the point that node doesn’t respond to /status
queries.

Stop getting the validator information when node is synchronising to
avoid this problem.  The observable effect is that

- near_validators_blocks_expected,
- near_validators_blocks_produced,
- near_validators_chunks_expected and
- near_validators_chunks_produced

metrics are not updated.

Issue: https://github.com/near/nearcore/issues/6763

title: First step of moving preprocess_block out of ChainUpdate
body: This PR moves preprocess_block out of ChainUpdate::process_block and refactors Chain::process_block_single_impl. Next, we can start to move preprocess_block to from ChainUpdate to Chain.

title: fix: verify that challenges root is empty
body:
Verify that challenges root of block header is empty, to ensure that any block containing a challenge is rejected. This is done only in `provenance != Provenance::PRODUCED` case, because otherwise protocol guarantees that block doesn't contain challenges.

## Testing

* `test_block_with_challenges`. If the challenges root check is removed, the test fails.

title: bumped protocol version (protobuf support)
Add function preprocess_block
body: Refactoring ChainUpdate::process_block to move the processing before apply_chunks to a new function preprocess_block. Later, the preprocess_block function will be moved to Chain, because there should be no chain update in this function.

title: added a metric monitoring Proto/Borsh encoding for peer connections
body: We will disable borsh encoding once node all versions >= PEER_MIN_ALLOWED_PROTOCOL_VERSION support protobuf decoding. Nevertheless, this metric will allow us to observe whether protobuf is actually used (as borsh is still enabled as a fallback).

title: fix: disable storage proof generation
body:
After releasing 1.26.0 on testnet, some validators complained about confusing "not implemented error". The root cause was chunk validation failure - e.g. due to node DB corruption or old supported protocol version. And only then node tried to create a chunk state challenge and failed because we don't support it. However, such misleading error must not occur in production.

Here we solve the issue by disable storage proof generation, because challenges are not enabled yet, so now unsupported `TrieRecordingStorage` will not be called.

Another option was to support chunk nodes cache for `TrieRecordingStorage`, but because it should be properly tested and we won't actually use its functionality, I choose the current approach. 

**We may want to include this fix into mainnet release if this is still possible.**

## Testing
* Update `test_verify_chunk_invalid_state_challenge`

## Note

It feels suboptimal that `create_chunk_state_challenge` was covered only by one test for which `receipts` was empty. If it contained at least one receipt, it would catch the error. However, the code of problematic function is trivial now.

title: Separate collecting rocksdb statistics and re-exporting them to prometheus
body: This PR lets us verify whether the performance impact is caused by RocksDB statistics or by nearcore re-exporting those metrics. If the latter, we can optimize the code to reduce the performance impact.

title: network: prefer strum::IntoStatiStr than strum::AsStaticStr

The latter is deprecated so use the former which has equivalent

title: rename debug pages: chain -> sync, sync -> network
body: ### Description This PR renames & restructures a few pages under Debug. The "chain info" page is merged with the "chunk info" page, and together they are now called "Chain & Chunk info", and the "sync info" page is now called "network info". The purpose is to group the page contents as close as possible and reduce the effort need to locate debug information. ### JIRA Issue [CP-82](https://nearinc.atlassian.net/browse/CP-82) ### Test plan - Build with make neard - Under `nearcore` directory, launch localnet using command `nearup stop && nearup run localnet --binary-path ./target/release` - Open your browser and go to http://[host_address]:3030/debug/ - Expect to see the link "Chain & Chunk Info" and "Network Info" - Click the link "Chain & Chunk Info" - Expect to see a webpage that looks similar to the one below - Click the link "Network Info" - Expect to see a webpage that looks similar to the one below ### Screenshot on testnet (includes changed pages only) ### First round reviewer - @mzhangmzz - @mm-near

title: network: replace strum::AsStrRef derives with strum::IntoStaticStr
body:
The advantage of strum::IntoStaticStr derive is that provided into
method returns a static reference rather than a one with self’s
lifetime which also creates a borrow on self.

Issue: https://github.com/near/nearcore/issues/6704

title: fix(params-warehouse): Use specified metric
body:
The parameter estimator is run daily and the estimation results are stored in an SQLite file uploaded as buildkite artifact.
This was introduced only recently and is still in the build-up phase.

I found a few bugs in the initial implementation that compares two estimation sets.
1. The main bug: `Metric::Icount` was hard-coded and the CLI argument was ignored.
2. The results for `before` and `after` were the wrong way around.
3. The function `commits_sorted_by_date` would have crashed if it was used without specifying a metric.

Test plan
---------
Added unit tests to db and check module.
This complements existing unit tests in the import module.
All bugs fixed by this PR are caught by the new tests.

title: test: check sanity of nondeterministic costs
body:
Follow up for #6605 which added `test_cost_sanity` to verify that costs don't change by accident. Some costs may be nondeterministic and are therefore ignored. For example, `gas_used` of `CONTRACT_LOADING_BYTES` is ignored since bytecode size depends on environmental factors.

This PR adds `test_cost_sanity_nondeterministic`, which checks the sanity of costs ignored in `test_cost_sanity` by calling a function on a trivial contract and verifying the resulting gas profile. For the trivial contract environmental factors appear to not make a difference.

Issue: #4961

title: move receipt_id_to_shard_id to be saved after apply_chunks
body:
This PR is also part of the initiative to refactor process_block so there are no writes to ChainStore before apply_chunks.
It also simplifies the implementation of receipt_id_to_shard_id by saving it as outgoing receipts at the block when the receipts are generated, instead of at the next block.

title: refactor how incoming_receipts are handled in process_block
body: The purpose of this PR is to move the saving of incoming_receipts in process_block to after apply_chunks. In preparation for making apply_chunks non-blocking, process_block shouldn't write any changes to ChainStore before apply_chunks. The PR may seem to make the code more complicated for now, but it will make sense with more following PRs of refactoring process_block.

title: Export structured traces data via OpenTelemetry to Jaeger
body:
Tested by running localnet with a local instance of Jaeger (`docker run -d -p6831:6831/udp -p6832:6832/udp -p16686:16686 jaegertracing/all-in-one:latest`)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/86772482/166255698-4034a4c0-f59a-4777-9ef0-749ffe240c94.png)

Issue #6731

title: Adding more debug information to the pages
body:
* gas price to the last blocks
* history of epochs & history of validators
* list of announce accounts for validators and which peers are used to forward the messages.

title: nearcore: add IS_ARCHIVE key to the database
body:
Since archival nodes no longer generate values in ColTrieChanges
column, it is now ill-advised to switch a node from being an archival
to non-archival.  The node will work but will leave some garbage in
its database.

To prevent users from doing the switch, introduce IS_ARCHIVE key to
the database which indicates whether the database has been used with
an archival node.

If non-archival node opens such database it fails with an error.  An
archival node, on the other hand, will make sure that the key is set.

Fixes: https://github.com/near/nearcore/issues/6522

title: replace use of lazy_static_include_bytes in tests with std::fs::read
body:
Replace use of `lazy_static_include_bytes` in tests with `std::fs::read`

Since we don’t need to include test data files in test binaries,
prefer reading the files via `std::fs::read` rather than using
`lazy_static_include_bytes`.  In release builds the latter results in
the file being read at compilation which is a waste of time.

Fixes: https://github.com/near/nearcore/issues/6665

title: doc: update some urls in readme
body: The original urls of the tutorials and api docs will all redirect to [getting started](https://docs.near.org/docs/develop/basics/getting-started), this pr corrects them.

title: test: work-around flaky tests

https://github.com/near/nearcore/issues/6724

title: test: fix regressed nightly test
body: Follow up to #6670

title: runtime: make test_cost_sanity independent of receipt hash
body: Issue: https://github.com/near/nearcore/issues/4961

title: feat:(params-estimator) Faster AltBn estimation
body:
Changing from 1k to just 10 inner iterations on estimating costs of
`alt_bn128_pairing_check` and `alt_bn128_g1_multiexp`.
The results still give the same mean with very low variance.

The benefit, `icount` estimations of all alt_bn128 related costs combined
goes from a few hours to just 3 minutes.

title: Add database get method latency metric

Add nightly feature flags to build inside docker, to allow icount
estimates of nightly features without hackery.

title: move mock_network and rename it to mock_node
body:
Move mock_network out of integration-tests and rename it to mock_node. This PR allows us to enable feature "mock_network/node" by default, which means that 
1) Users don't need to compile with --features mock_network any more
2) Some tests in mock_network now can be run with out --features mock_network and thus are included in CI tests

body:
This fixes an issue of the transaction pool growing indefinitely in non-RPC nodes.

Issue #3284

title: added Send + Sync to std::error::Error in core/
chain: map blacklisted IPv4 to IPv6
fix debug page crash when there is no block available
body: ### Description In `HeaderSync`, there is no block available. Debug page actually crashes in this mode by trying to access block 0. This PR fixes this issue. ### JIRA Issue [CP-60](https://nearinc.atlassian.net/browse/CP-60) ### Test plan (on testnet) - Build with `make neard` - Under `nearcore` directory, launch testnet using command `nearup stop && nearup run testnet --binary-path ./target/release` - Open your browser and go to http://[host_address]:3030/debug/epoch_info - Expect to see a webpage that looks similar to the one below - Verify that the page works in `HeaderSync` mode, too (You can clear all files under `~/.near/testnet` to force `HeaderSync`, but remember to set`"enable_debug_rpc": true`, under `rpc`, in `~/.near/testnet/config.json`) ### Screenshot on testnet ### Test plan (on localnet) - Build with `make neard` - Under `nearcore` directory, launch localnet using command `nearup stop && nearup run localnet --binary-path ./target/release` - Open your browser and go to http://[host_address]:3030/debug/epoch_info - Expect to see a webpage that looks similar to the one below ### Screenshot on localnet ### First round reviewer - @mzhangmzz - @mm-near

title: Remove usage of strum::AsStaticStr in favour of strum:IntoStaticStr
body:
Convert remaining usage of strum::AsStaticStr (which is deprecated
in never strum versions) with strum:IntoStaticStr which provides
the same feature without the need for a custom trait.

Uses of strum::AsRefStr could also be replaced but they are left as
is for now because conversion is a bit messy.  `msg.as_ref()` would
need to be replaced by `(&msg).into()` and this added borrow is wee
bit ugly.  We may do it in the future commit.

title: strum: reduce usage of deprecated strum::AsStaticStr
body:
strum::AsStaticStr derive and trait are deprecated.  Replace most uses
of them by strum::AsRefStr derive which serves very similar purpose.

Unfortunately there is a difference where the latter returns a reference
with lifetime same as ‘self’.  utils/near-performance-metrics currently
depends on NetworkClientMessages and NetworkViewClientMessages implementing
the former and being convertible to `&'static str`.  Because of that, those
two still use strum::AsStatirStr.

title: store: get rid of RocksDBOptions
body:
The setters in RocksDBOptions are never used and the object is only
ever created with it’s default values.  As such, the structure
provides no value.  Get rid of it.

labels.name: A-python-test
labels.description: Area: issues related to python tests

labels.name: T-node
labels.description: Team: issues relevant to the node experience team

body:
Currently running the sanity/docker.py test images results in NayDuck
worker machines slowly running out of space as they accumulate Docker
images built each time the test runs.

Change the test by adding a clean up step which removes the image at
the end recovering the disk space.

Fixes: https://github.com/near/nearcore/issues/6599

title: feat: Flat and differential runtime config files
body:
Replace the JSON runtime config file per version with a base
`parameters.txt` file plus differential files per version.
The `RuntimeConfig` remains untouched. But it is now loaded from the
flat list of parameters, that converts it to JSON structured data following
the exact layout we use in code, that is then converted to an actual struct
using serde derived code.

The new TXT files are written in a custom format for key-values separated
by a column. Keys must match a defined parameter and values are strings 
or integers. Differential files include old and new values with a `->` between
them.

The direct benefit of this is better readability for config changes and
an easier and less error-prone process of doing such changes.

Indirectly, this could be the first step to further clean up code
around gas costs.
(1) the gas profile could use these parameters to track costs instead
of its own `enum Cost`.
(2) The params-estimator can link estimations to params more easily.

Test plan
---------
The usage of `RuntimeConfigStore` has not changed, only how it is
created. Therefore, tests can ensure all stored `RuntimeConfig`
versions are exactly the same as before. And this should be sufficient
to confirm this change has no side-effects.

To implement this, we keep the old JSON files in the `legacy_configs`
directory. The test `test_old_and_new_runtime_config_format_match` then
iterates through all existing versions and compares the serde
deserialization with configs loaded from TXT files. This is all we need to
verify correctness of the parameters loaded through the new files.

The new TXT file format also comes with custom parsing logic. Therefore,
 a few unit tests to make sure it behaves the way we think in all
circumstances.

title: refactor: cleanup alt_bn128 estimates
body:
Replace flat arrays of bytes with array of elements. This has two
purposes:

* improve code's readability, making the number of elements (which we
  base the estimation on) more clear
* prove that with the API it's possible to just pass a slice of Rust
  structs.

title: integration-tests: remove assertion that fork_tail <= tail
body:
this assertion fails when config.gc_fork_clean_step <=
config.gc_blocks_limit.  Chain::clear_data() doesn't really depend on
fork_tail being at most tail, and fork_tail is moved up to tail
whenever it's smaller in ChainStoreUpdate::update_tail(), so this
condition doesn't really need to be satisfied.

title: Fix a flaky test `test_query_rpc_account_view_account_doesnt_exist_must_return_error`
body: by retrying the request is the finality cannot be resolved to a block due to no blocks being produced.

title: client: fix docstring of metrics::export_version
body:
I’ve changed implementation of the function during developement and
forgotten to update the docstring resulting in wrong description
getting commited.  Fix that.

title: Extra logging: current height while syncing
fix(contiunous estimation): Icount comparison
body:
SQL condition to select data from icount comparison also checked for
time metric condition, which lead to an empty set to be compared.

title: Rename ColFoo to Foo and use DBCol:: prefix consistently
body:
Previously, some parts of the code used `DBCol::ColFoo` while others
imported each variant directly via `use near_storage::DBCol::ColFoo`
at the beginning of the file.  Those two styles were mixed even in
a single file.  Since some of the code would need to touch many of the
columns, the latter approach resulted in some cases in a long and
unwieldy `use` statements importing dozens of enum variants.

To bring consistency and avoid long `use` statements, change the
code to use `DBCol::ColFoo` style.

With that change the `Col` prefix in column names becomes redundant
and only makes the whole identifier longer.  To address that this
change also renames all the variants by removing the prefix.

title: fix: 'chunk_id' is not defined in request_chain_info.py
body: small fix: resolve undefined variable `chunk_id` by referencing `args`

title: client: introduce `near_build_info` metric with node’s release info
body:
Introduce near_build_info with a constant value 1 which exports
node’s build information as labels.  Specifically, release, build and
rust version are exported.  See [1] for description how this metric
can be used.

[1] https://www.robustperception.io/exposing-the-software-version-to-prometheus

While at it, set near_node_protocol_version and near_node_db_version
only once (since they are always set to the same value) rather than
doing so each time statistics are printed.  Added bonus of this is
that those metrics are now set immediately when node starts rather
than the first time the stats info line is printed in the log.

Issue: https://github.com/near/nearcore/issues/5979
